title: rod liddle labour corbyn working class
story: Yes, it should have happened long ago, of course.Wednesday night saw a series of devastating revelations about anti-Semitism in the Labour Party from the BBC’s brilliant Panorama programme. And the direct but illicit involvement of Magic Grandpa himself in what were meant to be independent investigations.Even before that came out, three peers resigned from the party because of the vast numbers of Jew-haters in Labour.One of those to quit is Lord Triesman, a top bloke. He was once a very capable boss of the Football Association. He resigned saying Labour was “instit- utionally anti-Semitic”.And he added that “the experience of le in the party has become sickening”.Even Corbyn’s closest allies among Labour MPs have had enough of him. Diane Abbott, for example. And the Shadow Chancellor, the sinister John McDonnell.Other Labour MPs are sick of being bullied by the convocation of weird Maoists, Trots and Leninists who surround Corbyn. People such as Seumas Milne and Andrew Murray .All of this has helped Labour sink to an astonishing all-time low of  per cent in the polls — at a time when we’ve had the worst Conservative Government in memory. Or at least since John Major was in charge.And now the party has finally turned its back on the people it was set up to support, the working class.It has decided to back the idea of a second referendum on Brexit, junking its previous decision to “respect the vote”.Hundreds of thousands of Labour voters in the North of England will be lost to the party as a consequence, possibly for ever.So the knives are out for Grandpa and I don’t see him lasting much longer. It is now a case of WHEN he goes, not IF he goes. But even when he goes, what can a new leader do with this rabble Don’t forget, the party is controlled entirely by the activists. And those are the , middle-class, liberal lefties and perpetual adolescents who joined the party en masse for three quid to ensure Corbyn was elected leader.They have nothing in common with Labour’s old voter base, the working class. They are opposed to Brexit. They are in favour of Hamas, Venezuela and Cuba. They support identity politics, with its endless hierarchy of victimhood groups.So the likelihood, then, is that a new leader will also come from the juvenile far Left.There are some great Labour MPs who would make excellent leaders of the party — Caroline Flint, for example, or Jon Cruddas. But do they stand a chance any more, seeing how the party is It’s more likely we’ll end up with John McDonnell, an unrepentant Marxist who thought IRA bombers should be given honours by the British government. Or one of his and Corbyn’s proteges.It could well be the end of the party as a viable political force full-stop.Ah well. Time to say goodbye to Jezza. It was fun while it lasted, mate. In a really grim kind of way.GRIM viewing, wasn’t it  That leadership debate.Smirky Hunt trying to convince everyone he has charisma and stands a chance of winning. And our next Prime Minister, Bozo, incapable of giving a straight answer to anything.Can you imagine asking Boris the time “Well, ha ha, I think that’s a very interesting question. And some people may be prepared to tell you it’s eleven o’clock, or perhaps five to five. But I’m not going to do that. No. Not me. That’s for others to say.“I will tell you, beyond all doubt, that it is definitely not seven o’clock, and that’s the important thing, the thing voters care about. And that’s why I think I should be your Prime Minister. Because I will never tell the electorate it is seven o’clock when it isn’t. And, indeed, even when it is.“Does that answer your question, Julie ”GOOD – he’s gone. Sir Kim Darroch, our ambassador to the US.Caught out when leaked messages revealed he thinks Donald Trump is “inept” and the White House dysal.He had to go, evenhe has become a darling of the liberal establishment here for hating Trump.Here’s a suggestion. How about we get as his replacement someone who understands Trump and Trump’s appeal to US voters DO you really think Boris Johnson is going to get us out of the European Union  Properly, I mean, much as we voted for If so, pass the hallucinogens. I could do with getting out of my head too.My guess is we will leave in part, with a deal slightly weaker than the dog’s breakfast Theresa May put before us. And don’t be too surprised by a general election pretty soon. That will cheer us all up.Never have so many people been let down by their leaders. You can read about how Brexit was betrayed in my new book, The Great Betrayal, out next week.It’s a sorry story and it should make you angry. Mind you, it’s also quite funny,you have a warped sense of humour.THIS is Geronimo the alpaca. Take a good look at him because he’s not going to be around much longer.The Government has decided he must be slaughtered because, according to a possibly flawed report, he carries a strain of bovine tuberculosis. His owner, Helen Macdonald, is utterly distraught.The killing of Geronimo, and the wholesale slaughter of our badgers, has been forced on the Government by the farmers. They have way too much power.They create sterile landscapes on vast subsidies.It’s time for all this to stop. For our sake, as well as Geronimo’s.HAVE we ever had a member of the Royal Family who was smugger, more full of herself, more truly bloody irritating, than Meghan OK, King John was a bit of a t***er . . . but things were dferent in the th century. title: veterans save thousands discounts
story: The Defence Discount Service gives former and serving Forces personnel savings at nearly , businesses. But nine out of ten of Britain’s .million veterans don’t know about it.So The Sun has teamed up with the Ministry of Defence-backed ­initiative as part of our vital Never Forget Them campaign.We want all veterans to get a better deal when shopping or paying for services — including meals out, travel and even holidays — not just the , who have signed up.And we are calling on more businesses — of any size — to swell the ranks of the , firms offering money off.It comes after The Sun this week demanded our next Prime Minister back our three-part Veterans’ Pledge:Julia Cooper, , landlady of The Don bar, a hub for many veterans, in Stockton-on-Tees, Co Durham, said: “I can’t thank The Sun enough for standing up for former servicemen and women.“Many of the men who come here served in Northern Ireland and they live in fear of being arrested and charged for serving their country.”Key to the Defence Discount Service scheme is the Defence Privilege Card, which veterans can use in stores and at businesses large and small and get up to a third off. Discounts can be found online and via an app.George Rogerson, , who served seven years in the Gloucestershire Regiment, including three tours in Northern Ireland, hailed the scheme as “a recognition of service to the country”.The former Lance Corporal, who was mentioned in dispatches after saving the le of his wounded­ commander under sniper fire in Belfast, has used the discount card since .George, from Chirk, Clwyd, said: “Veterans like me did our bit for your country and I use my card virtually every week and save money. I don’t regard it as charity.When I show my card and get discount, it’s like a recognition of my service to the country and a ‘thank you’. I’ve lost count of the hundreds of pounds I have saved over the years.”Another veteran saved £ on his phone alone from EE. Yet virtually none of the veterans The Sun spoke to yesterday in The Don had heard of the scheme.Among them was Pete Gaines, , of Sedgefield, who served  years with the Royal Artillery. Pete, who has not worked since a heart attack at , vowed: “I am going to sign up and save myself money.”Or visit Google Play or the Apple App Store and download the Defence Discount Service app.The app allows members to search for discounts in their local area as well as browse discounts on the move.It is FREE to join butyou want the Defence Privilege card, which you can carry in your wallet, there is an admin fee of £., which lasts for five years.Tony Walls, , from Thornaby on Tees, was another in The Don keen to join in.An ex Corporal who served  years with the Pioneer Corps, leaving in , he thought the scheme was only for those still serving.He said: “I had heard of this scheme but I didn’t think it was for me. I am certainly going to check it out.”The scheme means veterans and serving Armed Forces can enjoy discounts ranging from ten per cent off to, in some cases,  per cent discount on thousands of everyday items.It is not just giants such as Starbucks, National Express, Jet holidays, Enterprise Rent A Car, Halfords and KFC that take part. Thousands of small businesses are also on the list of , firms — such as bridal shop Willoughby  Wolf, in Marlborough, Wilts.Victoria and Spencer Wolf only opened the shop last September but signed up to the DDS scheme because former Warrant Officer Spencer, , serv­ed  years in the Royal Signals.Victoria, , said: “We benefitted from the scheme with discounts on things like cinema tickets and when we became business owners we wanted to pass that benefit on to other veterans.”Already they have given discounts totalling around £ to serving soldiers or former servicemen and women.Victoria added: “The first thing I ask our brides-to-be is do they have a brother, husband, father or close ­relative who has served or is serving  I point them in the right direction. Spencer spent over  years serving this country. Being able to pass on some benefit is really important to us.”The Sun is urging more companies to sign up. And the message is already getting through.Last night food giant Iceland confirmed it is considering giving discounts to veterans.And Cadbury World in Birmingham said it offers a  per cent discount for the military, who can bring up to six people with them on a booking. They just need a form of military ID or be a member of the Defence Discount Service.We will pass them to the Defence Discount Service so your firm can help those who served and boost your business by gaining loyal new customers.The more companies that get involved the more we can help our ­veterans.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hms queen elizabeth third leak
story: The £bn carrier - the biggest warship ever built by the Royal Navy - suffered a flood after an internal high pressure water pipe burst.Big Liz is now entering a planned maintenance phase early while engineers investigate what caused the fault.She was due in later this week, but sailed back into Portsmouth on Tuesday night.The Royal Navy tried to play down the leak, calling it “minor.”But sources on board said the flood was “serious” and affected multiple compartments.The fault is feared to be a burst pipe in a highly pressurised salt water internal sprinkler system – designed to put out fires.Insiders claimed the leak had damaged some bulkheads and doors – and at points was waist deep.One source, said: “The official line is that a minor flood forced her back to Portsmouth but in fact it was a fairly serious flood.“A total of eight compartments were flooded and this is not minor at all.”Reports claimed some crew were at risk of drowning in the flood – but that was strenuously denied by the Royal Navy who insisted there was “no threat to le” during the incident.Insiders said the fault was quickly isolated and all the flood water had been pumped out of the ship.This is the third time the new carrier – the nation’s most potent symbol of maritime strength - has suffered leaks.The Sun revealed in  the new warship had a leaking stern seal - part of the propeller shaft - that insiders called “signicant.”Then weeks later an internal sprinkler system failed sending gallons of waters gushing from the ship’s ceilings to douse a non-existent fire.Despite insisting the leak was minor, officials admitted an investigation had to be carried out whenever something “usual happened” to discoverthere is a more “fundamental error.”A Royal Navy spokesman, said: “Following a minor issue with an internal system on HMS Queen Elizabeth, the ship’s company were required to remove a small volume of water from the ship.“An investigation into the cause is underway.”The spokesman said at no point was there “damage or breach” to the ship’s hull.They said the earlyof HMS Queen Elizabeth was a precautionary measure.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: As soon as President Trump announced he wouldn’t be speaking to our man in Washington, there regrettably wasn’t anything he could realistically do. title: iran standoff royal navy oil tanker
story: Irans elite Revolutionary Guard tried to take control of the vessel as it passed through the Strait of Hormuz - sparking a tense standoff in the Persian Gulf, US officials revealed.But HMS Montrose quickly trained its mm deck guns on the enemy boats and warned them off, they added.It has since been confirmed by Sky News that the warship also deployed its Wildcat helicopter to circle the Iranian boats in a bid to scare them off.The British Heritage tanker was being escorted through the flashpoint region by the Montrose amid feverish tensions between Iran and the West.But the Navy frigate rallied into action when the rival boats approached the oil tanker and demanded it change course into Iranian waters.According to the anonymous officials, the Montrose came up from the rear of the tanker and aimed its weapons at the Iranians - before issuing a verbal warning to get away.One of the officials said: The Royal Navy HMS Montrose, which was also there, pointed it guns at the boats and warned them over radio, at which point they dispersed.The other added: It was harassment and an attempt to interfere with the passage.A US aircraft was flying overhead at the time and recorded footage of the standoff, the officials said.The attempted capture comes just days after British Royal Marines seized an Iranian crude oil supertanker off Gibraltar.Commandos dramatically detained the Grace  tanker over suspicions it was carrying oil to its ally Syria in violation of EU sanctions last week.Iran later issued a chilling threat of retaliation for last Thursdays daring raid.President Hassan Rouhani warned on Wednesday that the UK will suffer consequences for its actions.He said: I tell the British that they are the initiator of insecurity and you will understand its consequences later.And Irans Major General Mohammad Bagheri warned the seizure of the Grace  will not go unanswered.A deputy commander of Irans elite Revolutionary Guards today said that Britain and the United States will regret detaining the oil tanker.Now an action that does not need ability but some stupidity has been carried out by them, Rear Admiral Ali Fadavi, a deputy Guards commander, said, according to Tasnim news agency.The American government, and also England, should not have taken actionthey had made the smallest calculation, he said.We had rented this ship and we carried the cargo. Their action was very silly and they will certainly regret it. Our reciprocal action will be announced.Confirming the Montrose standoff yesterday, a Government spokesperson urged Iran to de-escalate the situation in the region. The Government spokesman said: Contrary to international law, three Iranian vessels attempted to impede the passage of a commercial vessel, British Heritage, through the Strait of Hormuz.HMS Montrose was forced to position herself between the Iranian vessels and British Heritage and issue verbal warnings to the Iranian vessels, which then turned away.We are concerned by this action and continue to urge the Iranian authorities to de-escalate the situation in the region.Iran later accused weak Britain of lying about the incident in a bid to inflame tensions in the region.Tehrans foreign minister Mohammad Jawad Zar appeared to deny the Islamic Republics boats were being confrontational.He said: They make a claim to create a tension that these claims are not worthwhile, and raised many claims.Mr Zar also said England was attempting to cover their weaknesswhile blasting America for engaging in economic terrorism referring to the sanctions imposed on Tehran by Washington.Initial reports from the US said that five Iranian vessels had harassed the tanker.Responding to the reports, US Central Command spokesman Cpt Bill Urban said: Threats to international freedom of navigation require an international solution.The world economy depends on the free flow of commerce, and it is incumbent on all nations to protect and preserve this linchpin of global prosperity.UK defence officials have previously confirmed that the Montrose had been deployed to the region to perform a maritime security role.A spokesman for Theresa May said the Prime Minister is concerned about the incident in the Gulf and called for a deescalation.The British Heritage ship - operated by BP - earlier made an “abrupt” u-turn and ed to the safety of Saudi Arabia’s coastline on Sunday.It had been heading to Iraq’s Basrah terminal when satellite trackers showed it changing course.Tensions continue to rise between Iran and the West after the Islamic Republic last week announced it was upping its uranium enrichment programme.Tehran plans to increase its production beyond the limits imposed by the  Iran Nuclear Deal - which the US walked away from earlier this year.US President Donald Trump said the deal had been too soft - but it was still supported by other western backers including the UK.Following Irans announcement, Trump vowed on Wednesday that sanctions on Iran would soon be increased, substantially!Last month, President Trump called off a planned airstrike on Iranian military targets at the last minute in retaliation for the shooting down of an unmanned US drone.Iran had earlier been blamed for a series of devastating sea mine attacks on US-linked oil tankers in the Strait of Hormuz.

title: pilot turns blue emergency landing
story: The plane allegedly rolled in the air as terried holidaymakers watched the panicked plane crew try to help the unwell pilot - who they thought may have had a heart attack.A passenger on board the flight recounts: The plane suddenly lurched, a man emerged from the cockpit and fell in the aisle.“Later I realised he was the captain.“Stewards began to search for a doctor in the cabin, panic was growing.“The face of the collapsed pilot went blue then a young woman ran to him and started first aid.The plane started descending quickly - people were crying, as I was.“The landing was not soft, as it was reported but the second pilot did well, all the passengers applauded.The co-pilot of the Montenegro Airlines flight reportedly informed air traffic control of the situation and a decision was taken to land the plane as soon as possible in Kaluga  miles, southwest of Moscow.Tourists on board said the plane with  passengers and five crew “rolled” in the air during the drama.Another passenger, Nastya, said: “The captain was unwell, at first, the plane suddenly moved to one side, or even rolled a bit.“Then he came out of the cockpit and just collapsed and there was no doctor on board.“The flight attendants were worried and panicking.She said: “I feared for lives of my family on board the plane.”Nastya added: “Sometimes I cry during take off or landing, but I never cried as strongly as today.”Other accounts said the pilot had felt sick and went to the toilet - but fainted on the floor after leaving the cockpit, in full sight of alarmed passengers.The co-pilot touched down in Kaluga - “but the landing was not so smooth”, said one frightened passenger.The pilot recovered only when the plane came to a stop on the ground, reportedly saying I will have a rest for about  minutes and we will fly again!’”However, ambulances rushed to the scene and the captain was immediately taken to hospital.A tourist on board called Tatiana Smirnova said a young female passenger, aged , had provided first aid for the collapsed pilot.“She did well, but there was no basic medication in the first aid kit on board for somereason”, she said.Russian authorities said no-one was hurt during the emergency and Montenegro Airlines reported that the safety of passengers and crew was not at risk due to this incident.Passengers from flight YM were taken by bus to Moscow’s Domodedovo Airport where the aircraft had been scheduled to land.The captain reportedly fainted due to the low tonicity of his muscles, with doctors denying he had suffered a heart attack.

title: drink driver ploughs party brixton
story: Mustafa Esmail, , jumped into a rented VW Golf and sent party-goers flying outside the Red Onion shisha bar in Brixton, South London.One victim, chef Fuad Ahmed, , suffered multiple fractures to his arm, a broken ankle, a fractured nose and his eye popped out of its socket.Others were left with horrendous injuries that are likely to resonate down the years, the Old Bailey heard.Esmail has now been caged for  years with an extended license period of four additional years after admitting five charges of causing grievous bodily harm with intent.The court was told Esmail had been barred from entering the bar on December  as there was a private party so he started swinging punches at late night revellers.Sozzled Esmail then got behind the wheel of an Ubeeqo rental car and deliberately rammed five people who were stood on the pavement outside the bar at mph.The court heard Mr Ahmed had now lost his livelihood working as a chef and a mechanic because of the horric injuries to his arm, ankle and eye.He cant walk without crutches and is dependent on painkillers, which has affected his mental health.The chef said: In short, this person, the defendant, has ruined my le.Sentencing, Judge John Dodd, QC, said: You drove the car mercilessly and quite deliberately. There is, in my view, something particularly cowardly about the using of a car as a weapon.This was a shocking and terrying event, fuelled by at least drink.You were turned away because the venue was hosting a private party, you fought with the door staff before beating a retreat.Your parting shot was, however, to say that you would be back. With you at the wheel, that car plainly became a lethal weapon.Esmail, who has a previous conviction for attacking his mum, also admitted battering Aaron Thomson with a bottle outside a Brighton nightclub after selling him a wrap of fake cocaine.The thug also punched him repeatedly in the savage attack in  outside Coalition, which left the victim with injuries to his neck, head and face.He was give nine months concurrent for the attack after admitting a single count actual bodily harm against Mr Thomson.The prosecution offered no evidence on five counts of attempted murder in respect of the driving incident.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: naples underworld tattooed mafia drama photographer
story: Photographer Sam Gregg said he wanted to delve past the city’s rough image and show the human side to le in the city which regularly tops the European crime index.Famed for its beautul coastal landscapes surrounded by the glamour of the Amalfi Coast, Naples is a sprawling urban settlement steeped in a rich Italian history.However, the mafia-style syndicate the Camorra, depicted in Sky-produced drama Gomorrah, still holds power in the city.In January, , a ten-year-old girl was shot in the foot during a mafia raid on a group of migrants.Graffiti and tattoos featured heavily in the photographer’s work along with topless Neapolitans sun-worshippers.Most of the picture subjects are inhabitants of the Spanish Quarter and Rione Sanità, two of the town’s most vibrant areas.Sam said: “It is a documentation of the spirit and vibrancy of the people who live in these areas, who remain steadfast even in the face of adversity.”The project was inspired by writer Johann Wolfgang Von Goe’s phrase “See Naples and die” which referred to the beauty of the city.However, the wording has taken on a new meaning because of its high rates of crime.The photographer continued: “Although Naples regularly tops the European crime index rankings, the situation in the city’s central areas is steadily improving.“Unfortunately the media consistently plays a role in glamorising and propagating Naples’ negative image.“I am not discrediting this issue as it is a real and pressing matter, I am merely highlighting through my photography that the people affected are tangible human beings before they’re political units.”

title: house of commons staff bullied by mps
story: I HAD only been working for an MP for two weeks before the dark side of their personality came out.They would tell me off in front of my colleagues, telling me my work was all wrong.My expertise was constantly undermined and belittled. A text I got even said: “I’m the MP, you don’t get to tell me what to do.” And I was bombarded with rude messagesI left work too early.I was sent halfway across London to sort out an issue with their travel documents.Another time I was scolded for bringing the wrong shoes to a meeting.They once screamed at me because I hadn’t spotted something silly someone had put online about them and got it deleted within minutes.One thing that was particularly toxic was that staff members were pitted against each other - they would tell me they were about to fire my colleagues, or tell my colleagues they were about to fire me.They fabricated stories about us and told them to other people in the team - just to sow discord among us.Whenever someone left the room they would speak loudly about their ability, their looks, their weight. They would snarl, slam doors, give you dirty looks, tut, roll their eyes.But the irony was - they knew how to turn on the charm when they needed it, which made you doubt it all. They would buy us presents sometimes and compliment us.Even though they were so vile, the more awful they were to me, the more I wanted to try and impress them, and prove them wrong. You never knew when they would turn - that was scary.Only by naming and shaming will we see repercussions for bullying and harassment in Parliament - but I still don’t feel comfortable doing that.That could only comewe had a culture of openly talking about our experiences without the victims fearing they would lose their professional standing.I would still feel reluctant to name the MP who bullied me publicly, evenI stayed anonymous - I fear it would come back to me.It makes me so angry that despite reports like this, there will be MPs who will get away scot free, because no one knows who they are apart from the people involved.Offering training courses isn’t enough, especially when they aren’t mandatory. The MPs who have gone on that training are the MPs who least need it.There needs to be policies put in place to protect staff from being bullied and harassed in Parliament.Each MP can run their office as and how they see fit at the moment, it’s so poorly regulated.There should be really serious repercussions for MPs found to be bullying or harassing staff. Whether that’s being suspended, having the whip removed, or limiting their ability to employ staff until they understand how to treat staff and not bully and harass them.After I left, I spent a lot of time thinking maybe it’s just me and I am clearly so bad at my job anybody would have that reaction.This report has vindicated that I have been bullied and there is a systematic problem here.But it’s incredibly distressing to read it back, it brought it back what I and my colleagues had gone through.I do still struggle with confidence in the workplace even now, years on.And the MPs today who are blathering on about the report on Twitter, who are beating their chests and saying how dreadful it all is You can almost guarantee they are doing some bullying themselves. It’s just saving face.

title: shocking cctv armed machete raid family home kent
story: The two fearsome-looking men were caught in menacing CCTV images before they smashed their way in the home of Chris and Emily Bushby.Chris and Emily, along with their four children, live in the upmarket Knockholt near Sevenoaks, Kent.The raid happened in broad daylight on Monday, not long after the mum and kids had left the house to get a punctured tyre fixed.Detectives are now hunting the suspects.The two men were wearing tracksuits and stalked the house before smashing their way in, where they stole a number of items before fleeing.One can be seen armed with a large machete.Police are investigating the burglary in the pretty village of Knockholt, near Sevenoaks, Kent, and Emily has posted photographs of the raiders in a bid to track them down.The -year-old mum said: Luckily I was meant to be on the school run but had had a puncture so me and kids were out, so grateful for that.My son was the first person to run into the house and he said he thought somebody had made a mess of a room.I was confused and when I walked in I realised what had happened. It was shocking.I called the police straight away - before I even went into the rest of the house.I should really have been in the house myself. I only missed them by a few minutes. Usually, I would have been in.I couldnt believe it.In the raid, the men took some of the familys passports and sentimental jewellery.Besides the robbery itself, Emily was shocked at the weapon the men were carrying, making the intrusion a dferent ball game.She added: Why would somebody feel the need to arm themselves with a machete Thats what I keep thinking - and what would have happened to meI had been there.The traumatic ordeal has shocked the whole Bushby family, and Emily claims that one of her daughters has been having nightmares about it.Her husband, Chris Bushby, , told BBC South East: One of the guys crouched down and throws all his might to smash the glass of the French doors.At that same time they looked around and the guy with the machete is there looking about.Then they disappeared inside. They were really determined. Its scary seeing them do it - especially with a machete as well.They were called at .pm on Monday  July  to a break-in at an address.A spokesperson said: It is reported two men, one of whom was carrying what has been described as a machete, entered the unoccupied property by breaking through a rear door and stole a quantity of jewellery.Both men were wearing gloves and balaclavas. One of them is described as being stocky and was wearing a dark tracksuit top, dark tracksuit bottoms with a white stripe down each leg and black trainers.The second man is described as having a slim build and was wearing a light grey hooded tracksuit top with dark grey stripes on the arms and shoulders, light grey tracksuit bottoms and black trainers.Investigators have been carrying out a number of enquiries including forensic examination at the scene and reviewing any potential CCTV opportunities in the area.

title: cesc fabregas speeding land rover chelsea admitted
story: The Spanish midfielder, , who now plays for Monaco, today admitted speeding after he was pulled over by cops at a service station on December  , Wimbledon Magistrates Court heard.Fabregas, who lives in a £m home in Belgravia, admitted driving his grey Land Rover Sport mph over the zone limit near the Tibbets underpass on the A near Wandsworth.The star did not attend the short hearing as he is taking part in pre-season training for Ligue  club Monaco.Prosecutor Simon Maughan dropped a second charge against the footballer alleging he was caught exceeding the  mph limit on the A on  July last year.The Monaco midfielder was represented by barrister Christopher Martin, who was instructed by solicitor Nick Freeman.Mr Freeman, named Mr Loophole for his ability to beat driving charges, is the representative for a host of other celebrities, including David Beckham.Fabregas, who already has six points on his licence, could now face a driving banhe receives the maximum penalty of six further points when he is sentenced by District Judge Andrew Sweet on  July.

title: greece storm brit dad dive tree
story: Ollie Pitham, , was on holiday in Ikos Olivia resort, with his we and two young sons, age  and , when he was forced to e out the way of a ft tree as it fell towards his apartment.The ferocious storms ripped through a tourist region in Greece last night, killing seven holidaymakers including a toddler and an eight-year-old boy.At least  others were injured after gale-force winds, rain and freak hail storms struck the Halkidiki peninsula in northern Greece.Ollie, from London, describes how he and another family hed travelled with were walking their children around the resort when the weather suddenly changed.He said: “We were on holiday with our friends and their two boys and Id decided to go for a walk to get the kids to sleep while the wives had a drink.“The weather had been great, reaching C but it suddenly changed in a matter of minutes.“The lightning started first and within five minutes the rain and winds hit and people were shutting the bars and restaurants.“We were told by staff to get back to our rooms so we ran as quickly as we could.“The kids were crying and everyone was in a real panic.“It was so surreal and everyone just went crazy.”After getting his family safely back to their room, Ollie ventured into their private garden to take videos of the terrying storm.Ollie, who owns an interior design business, said: “I wanted to get some footage of the storm but heard a snapping sound.“If I hadn’t been paying attention it could have been a lot worse, it could have killed me.“It fell sideways and broke all the fencing - butit had fallen slightly closer to the building it could have done a lot of damage.Ollie said his boys were terried during the ordeal and the family were forced to pull the kids beds away from the windows in case another tree fell during the night.Thankfully all family members escaped the storm unharmed and Ollie says the hotel staff provided excellent support.Ollie, who flew out with his family last Saturday, said: “We were very lucky.“A lot of other trees fell too but the one in our garden was the biggest.“Staff came this morning to remove the debris.”Dramatic footage shows strong winds sweeping through the region, which is popular with tourists in the summer.Other British holidaymakers were trapped in their hotels, buildings were damaged and cars were overturned in the carnage.A -year-old man and a boy, aged two, who are believed to be from Russia, died after a tree fell on their vehicle, according to the Greek Reporter.Two elderly Czech nationals were killed when strong winds swept away their travel trailer in Halkidiki, police said.A woman and an eight-year-old boy, both from Romania, were killed after a roof collapsed on a restaurant in Nea Plagia and a seventh body was found at sea.Athansios Kaltsas, director of the Nea Moudania Medical Centre, said: It is the first time in my -year career that I have lived through something like this. It was so abrupt, and so sudden.Officials have declared a state of emergency in Halkidiki and Greeces newly appointed citizens protection minister is due to visit this morning.Such severe weather is unusual in Greece, where summers are typically hot and dry.Meteorologist Klearxos Marousakis described conditions as extremely unusual for this time of year.

title: charity helped secure 13m extra
story: AdvertorialCharity has helped secure £.m in extra benefits for poor families - could you be entitled to more money Talking Money offers free specialist advice and ongoing support when people need it mostShareByDave Masters:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL AdvertorialNick Leaman from Talking Money helps Kathleen and Emlyn sort out their finances"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLike many people in their s, Kathleen and Emlyn Doughty are not comfortable with computers. So when it came to applying for disability benefit, they struggled in a world of websites and online forms. That was when Nick Leaman came to the rescue. The advisor with Bristol-based financial education charity Talking Money came to their house, and took care of everything. “Nick is a hero to us,” says Emlyn, . “He comes over and immediately puts you at ease. He knows exactly what to say and is so knowledgeable. “I am from the old school, and to understand something I need it in my hand. I don’t even know how to switch a computer on. But everything is online these days. I can’t even print out a form.  We are just relieved that Nick came over and explained everything to us and help us out.” Nick’s help was invaluable for the couple, who are both disabled and struggle to get out, and were falling behind on their rent. Nick’s work with Talking Money involves helping people who find themselves victims of fraud or who may be struggling with debts and don’t know where to turn. And the financially qualied advisor helps people access the benefits they are entitled to, with free specialist advice and ongoing support when they need it most. Over the last year the charity has received more than , enquiries and helped more than , people with advice and casework.They have also secured £.m for vulnerable low-income households by identying and applying for additional benefits they’re entitled to, including appealing negative decisions around housing benefit, sickness and disability benefits and Universal Credit .The majority of Nick’s work is through face to face consultations in Bristol and the surrounding area.  And he says many of his older clients struggle with the internet. “Older people are missing out because they can’t navigate online. I do feel compassion for them. They suffer from a lack of knowledge and access to information. Many of the best deals are online too so they miss out in that way too.” But the majority of people Nick helps are of working age. “It used to be the case that they had racked up huge credit card debts. But it has changed. The issues are now that they are struggling to pay rent and utility bills because they just don’t have the funds. Often they are in work, but they don’t get given enough hours or just not being paid enough. Or it might be the case they are facing financial crises because of unexpected le changes, such as relationship break-up, redundancy and bereavement. “It is also scary how much fraud is out there and how many people get scammed. Fraudsters are getting increasingly confident and can be so convincing. I had one lady who received a text saying she owed thousands to HMRC. It was a con, but she almost fell for it and was going to pay even though she was barely able to afford her rent. The problem is thatyou are desperate you are more likely to fall for scams like this because you just don’t think sensibly.” Despite the enormous demand on him, Nick loves his work. “It can be stressful but it is also really fulfilling because you are here to help people.  Evenyou can improve their lives just a little, that can make a huge dference to them. For others it can be le-changing.” For more Stories of Local Pride, click here

title: what happens you ask alexa
story: NewsWhat happens when you ask Alexa medical questions - and its not always very helpfulAs the NHS links up with Amazon to offer medical advice via the Alexa app the Daily Mirrors Steve Myall consults the digital doctor to find out how good its service is.ShareCommentsBySteve MyallDeputy Features Editor:,  JUL NewsAmazons Alexa is set to answer peoples health queries by searching the official NHS website. "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter Amazon announced users can ask virtual assistant Alexa for medical advice from the NHS, veried by professionals, we put it to the test. Bosses hope it will help patients take more control of their healthcare but it seems you have to be careful to phrase your questions in a way the speaker understands. Viktoria Kaftanikaite, from Glasgow, was just  months old when she had electrodes placed deep inside her brain to treat a condition called dystonia in May. The rare genetic condition causes her arms and legs to flail about, her mouth to twitch and leaves her screaming in pain, unable to eat and causes breathing dficulties. It can be caused by inherited genetic problems,cerebral palsy or other brain injuries.    As a result of the condition, Viktoria has spent five months in intensive care at the Royal Hospital for Children in Glasgow, the BBC reports. Doctors hope the surgery - which involved drilling holes in to her skull and implanting electrodes - will improve her quality of le. It could also mean this kind of surgery is used on young people in the future.    Little Viktoria was diagnosed with a rare mutation in the GNAO gene and was referred to neurologists at Evelina Hospital in London. Her parents had realised something was wrong when she didnapost reach the usual development milestones like holding toys and holding her head up - but she should be able to learn these skills now.    The prospect of surgery was terrying for her mum, Patrycja Majewska. She told BBC Scotland: We were worried what would happen. You hear the words brain operation and worry. We were scared she would not wake up. Le was dficult. She was two-and-a-half. She was exhausted and had no le. She was basically screaming for two-an-a-half-years. She would cry in pain for up to five hours at a time and sleep maybe one in  hours. There was no decision really. If we didnapost try this, she would die anyway. During the four-hour procedure, which uses state-of-the-art robotic and intra-operative imaging equipment, surgeons drilled two holes the size of a p coin into the top of Viktoriaaposs skull and implanted two electrodes into the area deep inside the brain which controls movement.

title: jilted bride sells unworn dress
story: NewsJilted bride sells unworn dress after fiancé dumped her for wedding planner palDonna Bettiss, from Horsham, West Sussex, was supposed to marry James Routledge but he decided to end things weeks before the big dayShareCommentsByHelen Le Caplain:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsDonna Bettiss and James Routledge have split weeks before they were due to marry "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A jilted bride is selling her designer dress after her fiancé cancelled their £, ceremony to hitch up with their wedding planner pal. Donna Bettiss, , was devastated after James Routledge, , suddenly ended things last month after a seven-year relationship . Sheaposs now listed her £, Sophia Tolli aposMonteapos sleeveless tulle and sequin gown on Facebook for £ as it remains a constant reminder of what had happened.Their pal Paige Hannington, , had offered wedding advice over cocktails after she tied the knot some months before. But during a work trip recently, James and Paige drunkenly confessed they both werenapost happy in their relationships. James called off his wedding and began dating Paige weeks later.    Donna, from Horsham, West Sussex, said: I really liked Paige, she helped me so much [with the wedding] so I feel completely betrayed. I was distraught that someone I knew and trusted and was discussing such an important time in my le with, could do that to me. However the way I feel now is very paranoid to discuss how amazing my relationship is with any other woman. She totally destroyed my confidence. When James decided she was who he wanted there was nothing I could do but let him go. I didnapost cause them any problems or try to stop them progressing. I even saw them on a night out but I just left them to it. I wasnapost going to make their night out with their friends awkward so I kept my distance and kept my friends away from saying anything to them.  The day I let James go was the day I realised he no longer loved me and I couldnapost force someone to love me or stay with me, that would be selfish. “The dress has been at my uncle’s house until recently, but now it’s hanging in my wardrobe. “I can’t keep it, there are too many bad memories. I desperately need it goneI want to move forward and rebuild my le. “Having it hanging there is a constant reminder of what happened. “I originally listed it for £, on eBay but there was no interest in the dress, so then I listed it for £ on Facebook and wrote what my partner had done. “Since I wrote that I’ve received lots of positive messages.”  The advert reads: “Open to offers, never worn. Wedding was cancelled due to [redacted] fiancé. “Desperately need gone, cost me £, had it a year and it’s a constant reminder. “Sophia Tolli dress size  never altered.” Donna and James met in March  at a nightclub in Horsham, West Sussex, and the following day Donna searched for him on social media and sent him a message. Six months later loved-up Donna moved in with James who then proposed and presented her with a diamond cluster engagement ring. Donna said: “I instantly fell for him and we soon spent every single day together. After a couple of months he told me how in love with me he was. “We were both really, really happy and so madly in love - head over heels - I wanted to spend the rest of my le with him.”  The pair were happily engaged and bought a two-bed end-of-terrace house where they lived together with Donna’s cat Sammie. Bride-to-be Donna excitedly booked four-star Nutfield Priory in Redhill, Surrey, as the April  wedding venue and picked her dream wedding gown, bridesmaid dresses and busied herself making hand-crafted decorations. As Donna immersed herself in wedding planning, newly-married Paige regularly offered her wedding planning advice over cocktails. Donna said: “The whole time from June up until November was wedding planning. “Paige and I would meet up for a cocktail and she would give me stuff for my wedding. “She even gave me her spreadsheets which were a massive help. “We also did a lot of over text and Facebook and she would tag me in dferent things. In September Donna picked up her designer wedding dress and said the gown, which hugged her curves, made her feel like royalty. Donna said: “When I went to pick up the dress with my mum and tried it on I said ‘mum I feel like a princess’. “I felt so pretty and elegant and it struck me that I really was getting married and wanted to spend the rest of my le with him. “Mum was crying and other people in the shop were welling up too.”  However two months later, in November , Donna was stunned when James delivered the bombshell news that he didn’t love her anymore and the wedding was off. Donna said: “When he told me he didn’t love me anymore and that we weren’t going ahead with the wedding I was broken. “I collapsed to the floor and cried my eyes out. “I went for a walk to get away from the house to process what had happened - the James I had loved had gone. “When I came back to the house, he told me there was nothing to talk about. I had no option but to leave. “I rang a friend who told me to pack a bag and go to her house straight away. I was up all night crying my eyes out. Devastated Donna fled to her friend’s house as she processed what happened. Donna said: I didnapost go to work, I didn’t eat, sleep or talk. I didn’t do anything. My friend said she’d never seen anything like it. “I just went completely numb and sat in the same spot for four days.” Newly-single Donna eventually moved back in with her parents and lost three stone in weight due to the stress of the break up and not eating properly. Since the break-up Donna has slowly started to rebuild her le and met her current partner -year-old data analyst Nick Pashley four months ago. Donna said: “Last October I started to rebuild my le - I changed job and have been focusing on my wellbeing. “I met someone new on Bumble called Nick - he’s my rock. “If Nick was to say ‘let’s get married’ I don’t think I could go through it again as the experience has turned me into a commitment-phobe. “I’ve only just got my dress back as it’s been hanging up at my uncle’s house. “Now it’s in my wardrobe, the fact I know it’s here, I need it gone so I can move forward. It was really expensive but there are too many bad memories attached to it. “I put it up for sale on eBay but had no interest, since sharing it on Facebook I’ve had lots of people sending me positive messages of support, which has been nice.” Donna has yet to sell the dress but hopes a bargain-hunting bride will get the chance to enjoy the dress on her special day. Donna said: “It’s a really beautul dress and will make someone’s day. “The a-line dress draws you in at the waist and then it flares out and covers everything up, it makes you look like you have the tiniest waist.” James said: I paid for pretty much everything for the wedding. Donna paid for some small craft items to make personalised champagne flutes, but I paid for the big stuff. “Her dad contributed £ towards it but was reimbursed once the wedding was called off. Paige, a photographer, said: “Donna has never attempted to contact me to try to have it out. “It would be hard to hear that James and I are incredibly happy. “We’re in a fantastic situation and I’m aware Donna is in a new relationship. I personally wish her happiness. I was married to another person. I worked with James and we had been friends for three years and we went away, with other people, on a work trip and we got chatting.

story: NewsKate Middleton backs campaign to get more kids to connect with natureThe Duchess of Cambridge, , is throwing her support behind ‘Backyard Nature’ will encourage and support children to spend a million hours outdoorsShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsKate Middleton pictured at Wimbledon earlier this month "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge is backing a nationwide drive to get children to connect with nature and become conservation activists. A major advocate for helping children access outdoor space to improve their development, Kate told how “nature can play a pivotal role in helping children grow up to become happy, healthy adults”. The campaign ‘Backyard Nature’ - fronted by group of children from Anfield, Liverpool - will encourage and support children to spend a million hours outdoors to learn about their environment and take action to safeguard the planet. A new poll suggests that % of parents are concerned about future environmental challenges faced by their children, and the limited amount of time their children spend outdoors.    The Duchess said: “Spending time in nature can play a pivotal role in helping children grow up to become happy, healthy adults. “The great outdoors provides an open playground for children to have fun and learn le-long skills – from balance and coordination to empathy and creativity – with their friends, their parents, their carers, or their family members. “I hope the Backyard Nature campaign inspires children, families and communities to get outside and engage with nature, wherever they live.” Mum-of-three Kate, , was seen having fun on Wednesday supporting her husband William at a charity polo match against his brother Harry’s team.    The royal couple’s children, Prince George, five, Princess Charlotte, four, and Prince Louis, one, all played together in the adjoining fields, even playing with their new cousin Archie, Harry and Meghan’s newborn son.Young people, and their parents or carers, can sign-up online to become “Backyard Nature s” for their area through the website backyardnature.orgOnce joined, users can find their local patch using a map highlighting green spaces, download DIY guides and also find conservation events happening nearby. The campaign, funded by the Iceland Foods Charitable Foundation, was inspired by the Eco Emeralds, a group of young environmentalists from All Saints Catholic Primary School in Anfield, Liverpool.   The youngsters aged seven to  contacted Iceland’s managing director Richard Walker via Twitter and were invited to the supermarket firm’s head office to present their ideas, leading to the development of the campaign.Mr Walker said: “The nation is waking up to the immediate challenge facing us - far bigger than any of the other issues being discussed in the media at the moment, the environmental crisis has huge implications for us all. “The Eco Emeralds share my belief that the next generation needs to connect with nature and become conservation activists, and their commitment to motivating and enabling others to do this is truly inspiring. “I strongly believe that children need to know nature in order to want to protect it, and this campaign is about supporting them to do just that.

title: three horrific births gave ptsd
story: NewsThree horric births gave me PTSD but I felt guilty as Im not a war veteranSophie Butler, , refused to talk about her flashbacks, angry flashes and depression for years - but then her doctor finally worked out what was really going onShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  JUL NewsSophie with baby Sydney "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who developed post-traumatic stress disorder after extremely traumatic births with each of her three children said she felt the diagnoses made her feel she was taking something away from Army veterans. Sophie Butler, , was embarrassed and felt guilty when the doctors told her as she, like most other people, has always associated it with the brave men and women who serve in the armed forces. However the anxiety condition can occur after any form of extremely frightening or distressing event. She nearly died and lost her daughter Sydney during her first birth, and suffered horrendous fourth-degree tears during her second. She was then told during her third pregnancy that she had a blood clot that could have been fatal. She had flashbacks to her time in hospital, combining all of the traumatic experiences into one horric memory.Speaking during the Birth Trauma Association aposs awareness week, Sophie has shared her horrying journey and how she finally broke down and got the help she desperately needed after six long years in the dark.   She told : I was questioning myself. I was a bit embarrassed. I felt like I was taking something away from Army veterans. I was like, I donapost deserve to be diagnosed with this. I havenapost fought in a war or witnessed the things they have. But I just felt so relieved that finally after six years everything made sense. It wasnapost my fault. It was out of my control. My counsellor compared it to a car accident. Iaposve realised that I can talk about it. I just thought, why have I been putting up with it for so long. Sophie, who works in TV, and her husband Sam, , are proud parents to Sydney, six, Sadie, two, and -month-old Sonny.    Each of the births was extremely dficult physically and emotionally, to the point that sheaposs referred to Manchesteraposs St Maryaposs Hospital as Scary Maryaposs up until just a few months ago. Sydney - September  When Sophieaposs waters broke she was told to stay at home until her contractions got closer together however she then noticed the water was becoming a brown, greeny colour so she went in. When she was examined the nurses told her she was only cm dilated by the baby had pooed inside of her. They both looked alarmed. I just remember my heart sinking. That was the first part of it. Thataposs when everything started to go wrong. I just remember going into the toilet and thinking this isnapost supposed to happen. She was then taken by ambulance to St Maryaposs hospital in Manchester.  When she arrived they thought it would still be a while so they told Sam to go and get food, but when he was good things started to move quickly. Despite being cm dilated and trying to push nothing was happening, and then a doctor realised the baby was breech and in distress. Sophie had to be rushed down to theatre. Everyone was looking at her as she was wheeled down the corridor and into theatre with everyone looking at her and finally given an epidural. I just remember seeing my dad standing in the corridor, he just looked so panicked. Iaposve never seen my dad look so scared. However Sydney didnapost cry at first and had to be rubbed very vigorously before she made a sound.  It was so strange. It was like an out of body experience. It felt like years until we heard her cry. It probably wasnapost that long but it felt like it. It just seemed so touch and go. When they gave her to me I couldnapost top looking at her and wonderingshe was okay. I felt really scared when she was in my arms, I thought I had lost her. I thought I was going to lose her again. I had my guard up I think. She spent two nights in hospital before ing home to start their lives as a family. While it was an exciting time, looking back now Sophie knows that she was depressed. But she put on a brave face and didnapost tell anyone how she was feeling. Sadie - July  Because of what happened with Sydney, Sophie didnapost want a cesarean when she was expecting her second child. I felt like I had been robbed of it. I was ready to push Sydney out but I couldnapost. She went into labour at a sports day and before long her contractions were very close together. However she was still only cm dilated . The pain was incredible. It was coming on really quickly, I couldnapost deal with it.    However there werenapost any beds free so she had to sit in the waiting room. She was given some painkillers that actually made her fall asleep and stopped the contractions. That was really bad. They needed to get the baby out. I just have a memory of my mum in the corner crying. She was in a state of confusion which meant she wouldnapost open her legs and the doctors had to hold her down to try and deliver the baby. The baby had her hands on her head which meant delivery was going to be even more dficult than normal anyway, and doctors had decided they needed to cut Sophie to get her out. I just remember seeing these scissors and thinking there is no way youaposre cutting me with them. I donapost know where it came from but I got the biggest push Iaposve ever done in my le. I had been pushing for so long I had nothing left, but I just saw the scissors and thought aposnoapos.  Little Sadie came out with the huge push, but Sophie suffered a huge rip right back to her bottom. She had fourth degree tears which meant that after a very quick cuddle with her baby she had to be taken into theatre. I was back in that room. I just thought how am I back here  I just remember lots of people. I had had enough and I just passed out, I couldnapost do it. The second traumatic birth brought back horrible memories of Sydneyaposs birth and she struggled to cope with the flashbacks.  If anyone asked me about the birth I couldnapost talk about it. I just tried to ignore it. I didnapost tell anyone. I was petried of anyone going down there. My mood swings were really up and down, I just tried to ignore it. I didnapost want any reminders of it. Sonny -  In November when she was about five months pregnant, Sophie developed a cough and before long was coughing up blood. Doctors thought she had norovisus. Iaposve never felt as bad as I felt. On Christmas Day I was crying because I felt so poorly. On Boxing Day they went to a walk in centre where she was given antibiotics but it carried on, and shortly afterwards she coughed so badly that something popped in her back. I thought I had broken a rib from coughing so hard. I couldnapost move.  She was taken to hospital by ambulance but it was so busy that she had to wait on a stretcher for  hours until a bed became free. She claims she was given little information by the hospital, but was finally told she had a pulmonary embolism, a blood clot on her lung. She was sent for lots of tests and scans which left her feeling really nauseous and she was vomiting. They just said youaposve got a blood clot and it can be fatal. Just matter of fact. It was awful. I still find that really dficult to think about. Iaposve got my two girls, I couldnapost die and leave them. She was given drugs to thin the blood which started to work, but they made her birth with Sonny even more dangerous and she opted for a cesarean to reduce the risks. Thankfully his arrival into the world was straightforward and they were delighted to have a little boy to add to their family.  But in the weeks after he was born Sophie started to feel really down. After I had Sonny I felt really angry, like why did I have to go through all of that  I felt like I had a really short straw. A lot of my friends are having babies and they just seemed to push them out and have a great time and I didnapost. I was bitter as well, I didnapost want to be but I just was.

title: greece storm brits thought theyd
story: NewsGreece storm: Brits thought theyd die as golf balls from hell fell from skyLiz Travis said they sheltered her two-year-old grandson from hailstones on the floor of a taxi after getting caught in a storm in Halkidiki which has left six people deadShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video couple-shares-footage-terrying-greek-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,consentCookies:DUMMY_COOKIE,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,groupmDisplayPrebidEnabled:true,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,consentCookies:DUMMY_COOKIE,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,groupmDisplayPrebidEnabled:true,displayPrebidEnabled:true,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,videoPrebidEnabled:true,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British family caught in deadly storms in Greece told how they aposthought theyaposd dieapos as golf balls from hell fell from the sky. Liz Travis, , was on holiday in Halkidiki with her family when they got caught up in the extreme weather in Greece which has seen six people killed and more than  injured. The grandma described her family crouching on the floor of a taxi with their heads down, guarding her two year-old grandson as the storm lashed outside. She described fearing the car would turn over as it rocked, with tree branches hitting the vehicle on their way back to Halkidiki after visiting a nearby village. Liz said they were shaking, thought they would die, and said she began praying in fear despite not being religious. The sales negotiator from Bishopstoke claims they even saw a car appearing to slip over the edge of a clf and admitted she woke up from a nightmare this morning following the traumatic scenes they saw. Have you been caught up in the storms in Greece  Email webnews@mirror    Speaking to Mirror, Liz said: We thought we were going to die, it was horrendous. Iaposm not even religious but I started praying. I was doing cross signals across my chest. She added: We saw a power cable come down on the motorway. We saw a car slip over the edge of a clf, we just canapost believe it. The Greeks said theyaposve never experienced anything like it. I woke up this morning having had a nightmare and shouted aposget the car off the clfapos. I have been traumatised.  Liz and her family went on an evening excursion to nearby village Afytos, about  minutes from their hotel. As there were seven of them, they had arranged for two taxis to pick them up at pm last night. Liz was in the car with her husband James Travis, , her -year-old daughter Sian Yates and grandson Finley Yates, two. In the taxi behind were Sianaposs husband Jamie Yates and his parents. As soon as they got in the cars, thunder and lightening hit and all the lights went out in Afytos amid a power cut. Within two minutes on the road, golf ball size hail stones began falling and the taxi driver desperately searched for a safe space to hide.  Liz told: The taxi driver said aposIaposve got to pull over, there are stones coming out of the skyapos. She said aposIaposve got to find a safe place to parkapos. In minutes there were golf balls of hell coming out of the sky hitting the car. We couldnapost see where we were going, cars were putting their hazards on. We were only going a few miles per hour as the taxi driver couldnapost see, she was crawling. We found a driveway and pulled into it - five minutes into the journey. The gates were swinging back and forth. The car was rocking and we thought we were going to turn over. Tree branches were hitting us, we could hear the sound of the water gushing. When they stopped in a driveway, Liz said they all sheltered on the floor of the car. She told: We were all crouching on the floor of the car. We got Finley out of his car seat and positioned him between me and my daughter and we were guarding him. Finley thought it was a game. We were all shaking. We all had our heads down incase the windows smashed. Water was leaking through the roof of the other taxi. We couldnapost see the other taxi behind but the taxi driver rang through to the other driver so we could speak to them.  The family were on the driveway for about half an hour before they slowly made their way back to the hotel when the hail stopped. At the hotel they were wrapped in towels by kind hotel staff who looked after them as they were shaking and shocked, but luckily all the family members made it back safely. Describing the aftermath, Liz said the metal poles on umbrellas by the pool were bent in half, gazebos were blown over on the beach. Another holidaymaker, Bethany Cooper, was also affected by the storm in Halkidiki. She told : We were sat on a beach front restaurant in Hanioti when it all happened.  She said it was very sudden, adding we currently have no electricity or water in the hotel.  Bethany said: We were eating at a restaurant on the beach front, and the power went off which we thought nothing of and everything was calm.Suddenly, a storm hit and there were chairs and items from the tables flying around.Everyone ran to get inside.could hear people screaming and children crying - and people were trying to barricade the doors closed.Today we cannot get any power or running water. All the restaurants are closed and not serving food.

title: blether whistler jimmy was refereeing amateur games at the age of 80
story: Kenneth Brannan said he enjoyed the “absolutely brilliant article about my cousin, John Gourlay, which was submitted by John’s pal from boyhood, Gerry Cavanagh .”He continued: “As a schoolboy, John, who is  months older than me, was a great footballing prospect, but, sadly, for whatever reason, he didn’t quite get that vital break.“He ended up, very successfully, taking up a dferent type of career altogether.“John’s late father, James Gourlay , was also a remarkable and,I may say so, a wonderful person.“My Uncle Jimmy was very well known in and around Dundee for many years as a political figure and an equally well-known football referee.“Sadly, he passed away in .“In fact, Uncle Jimmy may well have set a record as a referee because, believe it or not, he continued to referee amateur matches until after his th birthday.”Kenneth remembers playing in a match officiated by his uncle.He continued: “That occurred just once and that was over  years ago when my team Tay Centre played a Sunday league match at Fairmuir. Before the game had even started, the late Bob Higgins and I were named as our team’s two substitutes.“Bob was not a happy bunny that day and he confronted our team captain, and said: ‘Why are me and Kenny th and th men ’ The captain replied: ‘Because we only have  available!’“We allhad a good laugh about that and I got my chance and came on during the second half.“Not long before the end of the game, my Uncle Jimmy, in his capacity as referee, made a decision in favour of my team.“It was a decision to which one of our opponents took umbrage to and he started to swear at the referee, who, believe it or not, was % against any swearing by anyone at any time – not just on the pitch, but anywhere .“He said to the player: ‘I can’t stand anyone swearing, especially on a Sunday. You’re off’!”Greenlee Drive resident Kenneth concluded: “I close this correspondence by askinganybody has any information of an even older referee ”

title: dundee drop nightmare made me better player says wright
story: Scott Wright believes the disappointment of relegation has equipped him to become a Dons regular.The winger is in line to feature for Aberdeen tonight against Finland’s RoPS Rovaniemi at Pittodrie in the first leg of the Europa League first qualying round.If Wright does play it will be his first competitive appearance in red since a - Scottish Cup win over Stenhousemuir on January .After that the -year-old was sent on loan to struggling Dundee.Wright impressed in his  appearances for the Dark Blues, but was unable to stop them finishing bottom of the Premiership and being relegated at the end of last season.However, Wright believes the pain he felt at Dens Park will help as he s to Pittodrie and tries to become a first-team regular in Derek McInnes’ side.He said: “Personally I loved Dundee, I loved staying down there and playing there. It was just bittersweet with the way it ended with relegation.“But it’s weird because going to Dundee was a good and bad experience for me.“It was good because I was playing regularly and I think it rounded off my football education and has made me stronger coming back to Aberdeen.“But it was bad because unfortunately Dundee were relegated.“Before the move we spoke about going away and playing regularly.“I went to Dundee and did that and I was part of the team. We were all pulling in the same direction trying to keep the club up.“Unfortunately we just weren’t able to do that.“From being at Dundee I’m used to playing more games and coming back here there’s a dferent kind of pressure. You’re expected to win every week and be at the top of the table.“At Dundee it was a relegation fight, but the games were just as important in terms of trying to stay in the league.“I think I’ve come back a better player with more experience and I’m hungry and ready to go.“If I’m picked hopefully I can force my way back into the team and keep myself in the team. The most important thing for me is trying to nail down a spot in the team and make it my own.“The pressure on us here is what you want as a footballer. It’s a case of channelling it in the right way to get results.”Tonight’s game will be the start of Aberdeen’s sixth straight European campaign under gaffer McInnes.In the previous five the Dons have fallen at the third qualying round stage on four occasions and the second qualying round last year.The Reds’ target once again in the Europa League is to reach the group stages.To achieve that they will have to come through four qualying ties.It’s a tall order, but Wright hopes this evening’s opener against RoPS can be the start of the journey to the groups and added: “We have to aim for the group stages and just take it game by game and tie by tie to try to get there.“Our focus is on RoPS and we’ll take it from there.“We know that they like to play a bit, but hopefully we can have the majority of the ball at Pittodrie and get on top of them and get after them.“The onus is on us to get forward because we’re playing in front of our fans and that’s something we’re looking forward to.”With a potentially challenging trip to Lapland awaiting the Dons next week Wright believes it is import to take a lead into the second leg.He said: “We recognise it will be dficult going over to Finland with the plastic pitch and the conditions.“Realistically we would love to get a win at home, but we won’t panicwe don’t.“We know the onus is on us to attack, but realistically it’s important we keep a clean sheet – that is perhaps the most important thing for us.“If we keep a clean sheet it gives us a  because the tie is over two legs.“We’ve been in Europe for a few years now so we’re experienced and know what we need to do.”

title: mcinnes and docherty agree new dons deals
story: Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes and assistant Tony Docherty have agreed new contracts to keep them at Pittodrie until .The pair joined the Dons in March  and have held the Reds to the League Cup in  as well as qualying for the Europa League six seasons in a row.Pittodrie chairman Stewart Milne said: “I think everyone recognises what Derek has achieved during his time at the club and I am delighted he has agreed to extend his time at Pittodrie, making him our longest serving manager since Sir Alex Ferguson.“The board and I strongly believe that with Derek leading this club we have a real  for further success, and I am confident the team he has rebuilt over the summer will continue to see us competing for trophies, keeping the pressure at the top of the league, and hopefully a strong run in Europe.“Derek also played a critical role in enabling us to secure consent for Kingsford and it will be a real milestone for the club to see him take his first training session in our first owned and dedicated training facility in our -year history.“I look forward to continuing our work together as we strive to deliver success for our great club.”McInnes added: “I am delighted we have been able to agree new contracts with the club.#The staff, players and I are committed to trying to deliver success and build upon all we have achieved in the past six years.“With the opening of our new training campus at Kingsford on the horizon I am excited about the prospect of training professionally in a modern facility, something which should be in keeping with the ambitious club we are.“It’s no secret that I love working for this club and I will strive to continue to try and create those special moments for our supporters. Working closely together I believe this is possible.“Lastly, I would like to thank the chairman and the board who deserve great credit for their backing this summer as we look to re-build a competitive team.”

title: countdown begins for pj live opening day
story: Today marks  days to go until the new £ million PJ Live opens to the public.A free ticketed event called Preview @ PJ Live is being held on Saturday August  to showcase the new ,-capacity arena which will host conferences, exhibitions and music concerts.There will be several test events including the public open days which are being held before the first conference, Offshore Europe, which runs from September  to . vw, px"  Alice Cooper and comedians Jack Whitehall and Russell Howard have already been confirmed to perform at the venue later this year and Elton John will also bring his farewell tour in November .Aberdeen City Council co-leader Jenny Laing said: “We’re at a very exciting point in the build and it’s been fantastic to watch it progressing since we cut the turf just over three years ago on July  .“We only have  days to go until people can come and have a look around and see for themselves the scale and quality of the council’s new title: praise for staff at north east home help service
story: A north-east home-help team has been praised for making service users feel comfortable.Monitors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited st Homecare Aberdeen on West High Street, Inverurie, on May  and have now published their inspection report.The service provides care at home for people in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire with a wide range of needs.Inspectors rated it “very good” for care, support, management and leadership – the second best of six possible ratings.They were particularly impressed with the emphasis on ensuring the same carers visit service users often.“People experienced a reliable and consistent care service, with the same few staff visiting people on a regular basis,” said the report.It added: “For this reason, people told us they were able to build a trusting relationship with their carers and felt more comfortable receiving care.”Citing one example where this approach had been successful, the report said: “This resulted in particularly good outcomes for one person who had always refused care, but the small team of dedicated staff took the time to develop a positive relationship, initially calling in for a chat.“After a while the person felt confident enough to allow care and this has enabled them to live at home for longer.”
